[30;1m403 | [0m[35m    A responder/watcher class noticed a 'bad' response to its submission.[0m
[30;1m404 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m405 | [0m[35m    Mostly used by `.FailingResponder` and subclasses, e.g. "oh dear I[0m
[30;1m406 | [0m[35m    autosubmitted a sudo password and it was incorrect."[0m
[30;1m407 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m408 | [0m[35m    .. versionadded:: 1.0[0m
[30;1m409 | [0m[35m    """[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m23[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000701[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.DataExfiltration.Token[0m
  Severity: [36mImportant[0m, Confidence: [36mHigh[0m
  Filename: [33m/invoke-2.2.0/invoke/exceptions.py[0m
   Pattern: [32m(npm owner|password|htpasswd|auth_?token|secret_?key|private_?key|authorized_keys?|npmrc|\.ssh|usersecrets?|api_?keys|nuget\.config|\.identityservice)[0m
[30;1m184 | [0m[35m        self.prompt = prompt[0m
[30;1m185 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m186 | [0m[35m    def __str__(self) -> str:[0m
[30;1m187 | [0m[35m        err = "The password submitted to prompt {!r} was rejected."[0m

[30;1m171 | [0m[35m    """[0m
[30;1m172 | [0m[35m    An authentication failure, e.g. due to an incorrect ``sudo`` password.[0m
[30;1m173 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m174 | [0m[35m    .. note::[0m
[30;1m175 | [0m[35m        `.Result` objects attached to these exceptions typically lack exit code[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m25[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000701[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.DataExfiltration.Token[0m
  Severity: [36mImportant[0m, Confidence: [36mHigh[0m
  Filename: [33m/invoke-2.2.0/invoke/exceptions.py[0m
   Pattern: [32m(npm owner|password|htpasswd|auth_?token|secret_?key|private_?key|authorized_keys?|npmrc|\.ssh|usersecrets?|api_?keys|nuget\.config|\.identityservice)[0m
[30;1m28 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m29 | [0m[35m    "Failure" may mean the command executed and the shell indicated an unusual[0m
[30;1m30 | [0m[35m    result (usually, a non-zero exit code), or it may mean something else, like[0m
[30;1m31 | [0m[35m    a ``sudo`` command which was aborted when the supplied password failed[0m

[30;1m274 | [0m[35munderscores: is ``INVOKE_FOO_BAR=baz`` equivalent to ``{'foo': {'bar':[0m
[30;1m275 | [0m[35m'baz'}}``, or to ``{'foo_bar': 'baz'}``? Thankfully, because env vars can only[0m
[30;1m276 | [0m[35mbe used to modify settings declared at the Python level or in config files, we[0m
[30;1m277 | [0m[35mlook at the current state of the config to determine the answer.[0m

[30;1m280 | [0m[35mvalid config paths (e.g. ``{'foo': {'bar': 'default'}, 'foo_bar':[0m

  Severity: [36mModerate[0m, Confidence: [36mLow[0m
  Filename: [33m/invoke-2.2.0/sites/docs/concepts/configuration.rst[0m
   Pattern: [32m\s(advpack\.dll|appvlp|at|atbroker|bash|bginfo|bitsadmin|cdb|certutil|cl_invocation\.ps1|cl_mutexverifiers\.ps1|cmd|cmdkey|cmstp|comsvcs\.dll|control|csc|cscript|csi|devtoolslauncher|dfsvc|diskshadow|dnscmd|dnx|dotnet|dxcap|esentutl|eventvwr|excel|expand|extexport|extrac32|findstr|forfiles|ftp|gfxdownloadwrapper|gpscript|hh|ie4uinit|ieadvpack\.dll|ieaframe\.dll|ic|infdefaultinstall|installutil|jsc|makecab|manage-bde\.wsf|mavinject|mftrace|microsoft\.workflow\.compiler|mmc|msbuild|msconfig|msdeploy|msdt|mshta|mshtml\.dll|msc|msxsl|netsh|odbcconf|pcalua|pcwrun|pcwutl\.dll|pester\.bat|powerpnt|presentationhost|pubprn\.vbs|rcsi|reg|regasm|regedit|register-cimprovider|regsvcs|regsvr32|rpcping|rundll32|runonce|runscripthelper|sc|schtasks|scriptrunner|setupapi\.dll|shdocvw\.dll|shell32\.dll|slmgr\.vbs|sqldumper|sqlps|sqltoolsps|squirrel|syncappvpublishingserver|syncappvpublishingserver\.vbs|syssetup\.dll|te|tracker|tttracer|update|url\.dll|verclsid|vsjitdebugger|wab|winrm\.vbs|winword|wmic|wscript|wsl|wsreset|xwizard|zipfldr\.dll)\s[0m
[30;1m273 | [0m[35mHowever, ambiguity is introduced when the settings names themselves contain[0m
[30;1m274 | [0m[35munderscores: is ``INVOKE_FOO_BAR=baz`` equivalent to ``{'foo': {'bar':[0m
[30;1m275 | [0m[35m'baz'}}``, or to ``{'foo_bar': 'baz'}``? Thankfully, because env vars can only[0m
[30;1m276 | [0m[35mbe used to modify settings declared at the Python level or in config files, we[0m
[30;1m277 | [0m[35mlook at the current state of the config to determine the answer.[0m
[30;1m278 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m279 | [0m[35mThere is still a corner case where *both* possible interpretations exist as[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m124[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000600[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Windows[0m
  Severity: [36mModerate[0m, Confidence: [36mLow[0m
  Filename: [33m/invoke-2.2.0/sites/docs/concepts/configuration.rst[0m
   Pattern: [32m\s(advpack\.dll|appvlp|at|atbroker|bash|bginfo|bitsadmin|cdb|certutil|cl_invocation\.ps1|cl_mutexverifiers\.ps1|cmd|cmdkey|cmstp|comsvcs\.dll|control|csc|cscript|csi|devtoolslauncher|dfsvc|diskshadow|dnscmd|dnx|dotnet|dxcap|esentutl|eventvwr|excel|expand|extexport|extrac32|findstr|forfiles|ftp|gfxdownloadwrapper|gpscript|hh|ie4uinit|ieadvpack\.dll|ieaframe\.dll|ic|infdefaultinstall|installutil|jsc|makecab|manage-bde\.wsf|mavinject|mftrace|microsoft\.workflow\.compiler|mmc|msbuild|msconfig|msdeploy|msdt|mshta|mshtml\.dll|msc|msxsl|netsh|odbcconf|pcalua|pcwrun|pcwutl\.dll|pester\.bat|powerpnt|presentationhost|pubprn\.vbs|rcsi|reg|regasm|regedit|register-cimprovider|regsvcs|regsvr32|rpcping|rundll32|runonce|runscripthelper|sc|schtasks|scriptrunner|setupapi\.dll|shdocvw\.dll|shell32\.dll|slmgr\.vbs|sqldumper|sqlps|sqltoolsps|squirrel|syncappvpublishingserver|syncappvpublishingserver\.vbs|syssetup\.dll|te|tracker|tttracer|update|url\.dll|verclsid|vsjitdebugger|wab|winrm\.vbs|winword|wmic|wscript|wsl|wsreset|xwizard|zipfldr\.dll)\s[0m
[30;1m229 | [0m[35m``INVOKE_``.[0m
[30;1m230 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m231 | [0m[35mNesting is performed via underscore separation, so a setting that looks like[0m
[30;1m232 | [0m[35me.g. ``{'run': {'echo': True}}`` at the Python level becomes[0m
[30;1m233 | [0m[35m``INVOKE_RUN_ECHO=1`` in a typical shell. See :ref:`env-var-nesting` below for[0m
[30;1m234 | [0m[35mmore on this.[0m
[30;1m235 | [0m[35m[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m125[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000600[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Windows[0m
  Severity: [36mModerate[0m, Confidence: [36mLow[0m
  Filename: [33m/invoke-2.2.0/sites/docs/concepts/configuration.rst[0m
   Pattern: [32m\s(advpack\.dll|appvlp|at|atbroker|bash|bginfo|bitsadmin|cdb|certutil|cl_invocation\.ps1|cl_mutexverifiers\.ps1|cmd|cmdkey|cmstp|comsvcs\.dll|control|csc|cscript|csi|devtoolslauncher|dfsvc|diskshadow|dnscmd|dnx|dotnet|dxcap|esentutl|eventvwr|excel|expand|extexport|extrac32|findstr|forfiles|ftp|gfxdownloadwrapper|gpscript|hh|ie4uinit|ieadvpack\.dll|ieaframe\.dll|ic|infdefaultinstall|installutil|jsc|makecab|manage-bde\.wsf|mavinject|mftrace|microsoft\.workflow\.compiler|mmc|msbuild|msconfig|msdeploy|msdt|mshta|mshtml\.dll|msc|msxsl|netsh|odbcconf|pcalua|pcwrun|pcwutl\.dll|pester\.bat|powerpnt|presentationhost|pubprn\.vbs|rcsi|reg|regasm|regedit|register-cimprovider|regsvcs|regsvr32|rpcping|rundll32|runonce|runscripthelper|sc|schtasks|scriptrunner|setupapi\.dll|shdocvw\.dll|shell32\.dll|slmgr\.vbs|sqldumper|sqlps|sqltoolsps|squirrel|syncappvpublishingserver|syncappvpublishingserver\.vbs|syssetup\.dll|te|tracker|tttracer|update|url\.dll|verclsid|vsjitdebugger|wab|winrm\.vbs|winword|wmic|wscript|wsl|wsreset|xwizard|zipfldr\.dll)\s[0m
[30;1m147 | [0m[35m  parsing and/or config loading.[0m
[30;1m148 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m149 | [0m[35m- A small config tree, ``timeouts``, holds various kinds of timeout controls.[0m
[30;1m150 | [0m[35m  At present, for Invoke, this only holds a ``command`` subkey, which controls[0m
[30;1m151 | [0m[35m  subprocess execution timeouts.[0m
[30;1m152 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m153 | [0m[35m    - Client code often adds more to this tree, and Invoke itself may add more[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m126[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000600[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Windows[0m
  Severity: [36mModerate[0m, Confidence: [36mLow[0m
  Filename: [33m/invoke-2.2.0/sites/docs/concepts/configuration.rst[0m
   Pattern: [32m\s(advpack\.dll|appvlp|at|atbroker|bash|bginfo|bitsadmin|cdb|certutil|cl_invocation\.ps1|cl_mutexverifiers\.ps1|cmd|cmdkey|cmstp|comsvcs\.dll|control|csc|cscript|csi|devtoolslauncher|dfsvc|diskshadow|dnscmd|dnx|dotnet|dxcap|esentutl|eventvwr|excel|expand|extexport|extrac32|findstr|forfiles|ftp|gfxdownloadwrapper|gpscript|hh|ie4uinit|ieadvpack\.dll|ieaframe\.dll|ic|infdefaultinstall|installutil|jsc|makecab|manage-bde\.wsf|mavinject|mftrace|microsoft\.workflow\.compiler|mmc|msbuild|msconfig|msdeploy|msdt|mshta|mshtml\.dll|msc|msxsl|netsh|odbcconf|pcalua|pcwrun|pcwutl\.dll|pester\.bat|powerpnt|presentationhost|pubprn\.vbs|rcsi|reg|regasm|regedit|register-cimprovider|regsvcs|regsvr32|rpcping|rundll32|runonce|runscripthelper|sc|schtasks|scriptrunner|setupapi\.dll|shdocvw\.dll|shell32\.dll|slmgr\.vbs|sqldumper|sqlps|sqltoolsps|squirrel|syncappvpublishingserver|syncappvpublishingserver\.vbs|syssetup\.dll|te|tracker|tttracer|update|url\.dll|verclsid|vsjitdebugger|wab|winrm\.vbs|winword|wmic|wscript|wsl|wsreset|xwizard|zipfldr\.dll)\s[0m
[30;1m131 | [0m[35m        While it's possible to store this setting, like any other, in[0m
[30;1m132 | [0m[35m        :doc:`configuration files </concepts/configuration>` -- doing so is[0m
[30;1m133 | [0m[35m        inherently insecure. We highly recommend filling this config value in[0m
[30;1m134 | [0m[35m        at runtime from a secrets management system of some kind.[0m
[30;1m135 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m136 | [0m[35m    - ``sudo.prompt`` holds the sudo password prompt text, which is both[0m
[30;1m137 | [0m[35m      supplied to ``sudo -p``, and searched for when performing[0m

[30;1m81 | [0m[35m- The ``tasks`` config tree holds settings relating to task execution.[0m
[30;1m82 | [0m[35m[0m

[30;1m85 | [0m[35m    - ``tasks.auto_dash_names`` controls whether task and collection names have[0m
[30;1m86 | [0m[35m      underscores turned to dashes on the CLI. Default: ``True``. See also[0m

[30;1m64 | [0m[35m============================[0m
[30;1m65 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m66 | [0m[35mBelow is a list of all the configuration values and/or section Invoke itself[0m
[30;1m67 | [0m[35muses to control behaviors such as `.Context.run`'s ``echo`` and ``pty``[0m
[30;1m68 | [0m[35mflags, task deduplication, and so forth.[0m
[30;1m69 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m70 | [0m[35m.. note::[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m129[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000600[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Windows[0m

[30;1m55 | [0m[35m   ``inv -f /random/path/to/config_file.yaml``. This path may also be set via the[0m
[30;1m56 | [0m[35m   ``INVOKE_RUNTIME_CONFIG`` env var.[0m
[30;1m57 | [0m[35m#. **Command-line flags** for certain core settings, such as :option:`-e`.[0m
[30;1m58 | [0m[35m#. **Modifications made by user code** at runtime.[0m

[30;1m60 | [0m[35m[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m130[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m

[30;1m460 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m461 | [0m[35mFor this example, that sort of local-to-project conf file makes the most sense,[0m
[30;1m462 | [0m[35mbut don't forget that the :ref:`config hierarchy <config-hierarchy>` offers[0m
[30;1m463 | [0m[35madditional configuration methods which may be suitable depending on your needs.[0m
[30;1m464 | [0m[35m[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m131[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000610[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Linux[0m
  Severity: [36mModerate[0m, Confidence: [36mLow[0m
  Filename: [33m/invoke-2.2.0/sites/docs/concepts/configuration.rst[0m
   Pattern: [32m\s(apt|apt\-get|aria2c|arp|ash|awk|base64|bash|bpftrace|busybox|cat|chmod|chown|cp|cpan|cpulimit|crontab|csh|curl|cut|dash|dd|diff|dmesg|dmsetup|dnf|docker|dpkg|easy_install|ed|emacs|env|expand|expect|facter|find|finger|flock|fmt|ftp|gawk|gdb|gimp|git|grep|head|iftop|ionice|ip|irb|jjs|journalctl|jrunscript|ksh|ld\.so|ldconfig|logsave|ltrace|lua|mail|mawk|mount|mtr|mv|mysql|nano|nawk|nc|nice|nl|nmap|node|od|openssl|perl|pg|php|pic|pico|pip|puppet|readelf|red|rlogin|rlwrap|rpm|rpmquery|rsync|ruby|run\-mailcap|run\-parts|rvim|scp|screen|script|sed|service|setarch|sftp|shuf|smbclient|socat|sort|sqlite3|ssh|start\-stop\-daemon|stdbuf|strace|systemctl|tail|tar|taskset|tclsh|tcpdump|tee|telnet|tftp|time|timeout|tmux|top|ul|unexpand|uniq|unshare|vi|vim|watch|wget|whois|wish|xargs|xxd|yum|zsh|zypper)\s[0m
[30;1m281 | [0m[35m'otherdefault'}``). In this situation, we honor the `Zen of Python[0m
[30;1m282 | [0m[35m<http://zen-of-python.info/in-the-face-of-ambiguity-refuse-the-temptation-to-guess.html#12>`_[0m
[30;1m283 | [0m[35mand refuse to guess; an error is raised instead, counseling users to modify[0m
[30;1m284 | [0m[35mtheir configuration layout or avoid using env vars for the setting in question.[0m
[30;1m285 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m286 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m287 | [0m[35m.. _collection-configuration:[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m132[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000610[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Linux[0m
  Severity: [36mModerate[0m, Confidence: [36mLow[0m
  Filename: [33m/invoke-2.2.0/sites/docs/concepts/configuration.rst[0m
   Pattern: [32m\s(apt|apt\-get|aria2c|arp|ash|awk|base64|bash|bpftrace|busybox|cat|chmod|chown|cp|cpan|cpulimit|crontab|csh|curl|cut|dash|dd|diff|dmesg|dmsetup|dnf|docker|dpkg|easy_install|ed|emacs|env|expand|expect|facter|find|finger|flock|fmt|ftp|gawk|gdb|gimp|git|grep|head|iftop|ionice|ip|irb|jjs|journalctl|jrunscript|ksh|ld\.so|ldconfig|logsave|ltrace|lua|mail|mawk|mount|mtr|mv|mysql|nano|nawk|nc|nice|nl|nmap|node|od|openssl|perl|pg|php|pic|pico|pip|puppet|readelf|red|rlogin|rlwrap|rpm|rpmquery|rsync|ruby|run\-mailcap|run\-parts|rvim|scp|screen|script|sed|service|setarch|sftp|shuf|smbclient|socat|sort|sqlite3|ssh|start\-stop\-daemon|stdbuf|strace|systemctl|tail|tar|taskset|tclsh|tcpdump|tee|telnet|tftp|time|timeout|tmux|top|ul|unexpand|uniq|unshare|vi|vim|watch|wget|whois|wish|xargs|xxd|yum|zsh|zypper)\s[0m
[30;1m272 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m273 | [0m[35mHowever, ambiguity is introduced when the settings names themselves contain[0m
[30;1m274 | [0m[35munderscores: is ``INVOKE_FOO_BAR=baz`` equivalent to ``{'foo': {'bar':[0m
[30;1m275 | [0m[35m'baz'}}``, or to ``{'foo_bar': 'baz'}``? Thankfully, because env vars can only[0m
[30;1m276 | [0m[35mbe used to modify settings declared at the Python level or in config files, we[0m
[30;1m277 | [0m[35mlook at the current state of the config to determine the answer.[0m
[30;1m278 | [0m[35m[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m133[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000610[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Linux[0m
  Severity: [36mModerate[0m, Confidence: [36mLow[0m
  Filename: [33m/invoke-2.2.0/sites/docs/concepts/configuration.rst[0m
   Pattern: [32m\s(apt|apt\-get|aria2c|arp|ash|awk|base64|bash|bpftrace|busybox|cat|chmod|chown|cp|cpan|cpulimit|crontab|csh|curl|cut|dash|dd|diff|dmesg|dmsetup|dnf|docker|dpkg|easy_install|ed|emacs|env|expand|expect|facter|find|finger|flock|fmt|ftp|gawk|gdb|gimp|git|grep|head|iftop|ionice|ip|irb|jjs|journalctl|jrunscript|ksh|ld\.so|ldconfig|logsave|ltrace|lua|mail|mawk|mount|mtr|mv|mysql|nano|nawk|nc|nice|nl|nmap|node|od|openssl|perl|pg|php|pic|pico|pip|puppet|readelf|red|rlogin|rlwrap|rpm|rpmquery|rsync|ruby|run\-mailcap|run\-parts|rvim|scp|screen|script|sed|service|setarch|sftp|shuf|smbclient|socat|sort|sqlite3|ssh|start\-stop\-daemon|stdbuf|strace|systemctl|tail|tar|taskset|tclsh|tcpdump|tee|telnet|tftp|time|timeout|tmux|top|ul|unexpand|uniq|unshare|vi|vim|watch|wget|whois|wish|xargs|xxd|yum|zsh|zypper)\s[0m
[30;1m257 | [0m[35m  constructors for the incoming value.[0m
[30;1m258 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m259 | [0m[35m    - For example, a ``foobar`` setting whose default value is the integer[0m
[30;1m260 | [0m[35m      ``1`` will run all env var inputs through `int`, and thus ``FOOBAR=5``[0m
[30;1m261 | [0m[35m      will result in the Python value ``5``, not ``"5"``.[0m
[30;1m262 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m263 | [0m[35m.. _env-var-nesting:[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m134[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000610[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Linux[0m
  Severity: [36mModerate[0m, Confidence: [36mLow[0m
  Filename: [33m/invoke-2.2.0/sites/docs/concepts/configuration.rst[0m
   Pattern: [32m\s(apt|apt\-get|aria2c|arp|ash|awk|base64|bash|bpftrace|busybox|cat|chmod|chown|cp|cpan|cpulimit|crontab|csh|curl|cut|dash|dd|diff|dmesg|dmsetup|dnf|docker|dpkg|easy_install|ed|emacs|env|expand|expect|facter|find|finger|flock|fmt|ftp|gawk|gdb|gimp|git|grep|head|iftop|ionice|ip|irb|jjs|journalctl|jrunscript|ksh|ld\.so|ldconfig|logsave|ltrace|lua|mail|mawk|mount|mtr|mv|mysql|nano|nawk|nc|nice|nl|nmap|node|od|openssl|perl|pg|php|pic|pico|pip|puppet|readelf|red|rlogin|rlwrap|rpm|rpmquery|rsync|ruby|run\-mailcap|run\-parts|rvim|scp|screen|script|sed|service|setarch|sftp|shuf|smbclient|socat|sort|sqlite3|ssh|start\-stop\-daemon|stdbuf|strace|systemctl|tail|tar|taskset|tclsh|tcpdump|tee|telnet|tftp|time|timeout|tmux|top|ul|unexpand|uniq|unshare|vi|vim|watch|wget|whois|wish|xargs|xxd|yum|zsh|zypper)\s[0m
[30;1m236 | [0m[35mType casting[0m
[30;1m237 | [0m[35m------------[0m
[30;1m238 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m239 | [0m[35mSince env vars can only be used to override existing settings, the previous[0m
[30;1m240 | [0m[35mvalue of a given setting is used as a guide in casting the strings we get back[0m
[30;1m241 | [0m[35mfrom the shell:[0m
[30;1m242 | [0m[35m[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m135[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000610[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Linux[0m
  Severity: [36mModerate[0m, Confidence: [36mLow[0m

   Pattern: [32m\s(apt|apt\-get|aria2c|arp|ash|awk|base64|bash|bpftrace|busybox|cat|chmod|chown|cp|cpan|cpulimit|crontab|csh|curl|cut|dash|dd|diff|dmesg|dmsetup|dnf|docker|dpkg|easy_install|ed|emacs|env|expand|expect|facter|find|finger|flock|fmt|ftp|gawk|gdb|gimp|git|grep|head|iftop|ionice|ip|irb|jjs|journalctl|jrunscript|ksh|ld\.so|ldconfig|logsave|ltrace|lua|mail|mawk|mount|mtr|mv|mysql|nano|nawk|nc|nice|nl|nmap|node|od|openssl|perl|pg|php|pic|pico|pip|puppet|readelf|red|rlogin|rlwrap|rpm|rpmquery|rsync|ruby|run\-mailcap|run\-parts|rvim|scp|screen|script|sed|service|setarch|sftp|shuf|smbclient|socat|sort|sqlite3|ssh|start\-stop\-daemon|stdbuf|strace|systemctl|tail|tar|taskset|tclsh|tcpdump|tee|telnet|tftp|time|timeout|tmux|top|ul|unexpand|uniq|unshare|vi|vim|watch|wget|whois|wish|xargs|xxd|yum|zsh|zypper)\s[0m
[30;1m225 | [0m[35mBasic rules[0m
[30;1m226 | [0m[35m-----------[0m
[30;1m227 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m228 | [0m[35mTo mitigate the shell namespace problem, we simply prefix all our env vars with[0m
[30;1m229 | [0m[35m``INVOKE_``.[0m
[30;1m230 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m231 | [0m[35mNesting is performed via underscore separation, so a setting that looks like[0m

[30;1m217 | [0m[35mbase.[0m
[30;1m218 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m219 | [0m[35mIn addition, due to implementation concerns, env vars must be pre-determined by[0m
[30;1m220 | [0m[35mthe levels below them in the config hierarchy (in other words - env vars may[0m
[30;1m221 | [0m[35monly be used to override existing config values). If you need Invoke to[0m
[30;1m222 | [0m[35munderstand a ``FOOBAR`` environment variable, you must first declare a[0m
[30;1m223 | [0m[35m``foobar`` setting in a configuration file or in your task collections.[0m

[30;1m37 | [0m[35m       and the final result forms the basis of the overall configuration setup.[0m
[30;1m38 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m39 | [0m[35m#. **System-level configuration file** stored in ``/etc/``, such as[0m

[30;1m253 | [0m[35mThis is more of a general software engineering tactic, but the natural endpoint[0m
[30;1m254 | [0m[35mof the above code examples would be where your primary logic doesn't care about[0m
[30;1m255 | [0m[35mInvoke at all -- only about basic Python (or locally defined) data types. This[0m
[30;1m256 | [0m[35mallows you to test logic in isolation and either ignore testing the Invoke side[0m
[30;1m257 | [0m[35mof things, or write targeted tests solely for where your code interfaces with[0m
[30;1m258 | [0m[35mInvoke.[0m

[30;1m59 | [0m[35mStarting in Invoke 1.5, `.MockContext` will attempt to import the ``mock``[0m
[30;1m60 | [0m[35mlibrary at instantiation time and wrap its methods within ``Mock`` objects.[0m
[30;1m61 | [0m[35mThis lets you not only present realistic return values to your code, but make[0m
[30;1m62 | [0m[35mtest assertions about what commands your code is running.[0m
[30;1m63 | [0m[35m[0m

[30;1m68 | [0m[35m    @task[0m

[30;1m27 | [0m[35mtheir methods (most task-oriented code) will find it easy to test by injecting[0m
[30;1m28 | [0m[35m`.MockContext` objects which have been instantiated to yield partial `.Result`[0m
[30;1m29 | [0m[35mobjects.[0m

[30;1m11 | [0m[35mSubclass & modify Invoke 'internals'[0m
[30;1m12 | [0m[35m====================================[0m
[30;1m13 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m14 | [0m[35mA quick foreword: most users will find the subsequent approaches suitable, but[0m
[30;1m15 | [0m[35madvanced users should note that Invoke has been designed so it is itself easily[0m
[30;1m16 | [0m[35mtestable. This means that in many cases, even Invoke's "internals" are exposed[0m
[30;1m17 | [0m[35mas low/no-shared-responsibility, publicly documented classes which can be[0m

[30;1m35 | [0m[35m      amount of subprocess IO testing that even the ``sys``  capture screws up[0m
[30;1m36 | [0m[35m    - setting ``verbose=False`` because we have a large number of tests and[0m
[30;1m37 | [0m[35m      skipping verbose output by default is a ~20% time savings.)[0m
[30;1m38 | [0m[35m    """[0m
[30;1m39 | [0m[35m    # TODO: update test suite to use c.config.run.in_stream = False globally.[0m

[30;1m202 | [0m[35m===================[0m
[30;1m203 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m204 | [0m[35mRight now, our ``tasks.py`` is implicitly for documentation only, but maybe our[0m
[30;1m205 | [0m[35mproject needs other non-doc things, like packaging/deploying, testing, etc. At[0m
[30;1m206 | [0m[35mthat point, a single flat namespace isn't enough, so Invoke lets you easily[0m
[30;1m207 | [0m[35mbuild a :doc:`nested namespace <concepts/namespaces>`. Here's a quick example.[0m
[30;1m208 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m209 | [0m[35mLet's first rename our ``tasks.py`` to be ``docs.py``; no other changes are[0m

[30;1m175 | [0m[35mthese is to select one or more other tasks you wish to always run prior to[0m
[30;1m176 | [0m[35mexecution of your task, indicated by name.[0m

[30;1m178 | [0m[35mLet's expand our docs builder with a new cleanup task that runs before every[0m

[30;1m180 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m181 | [0m[35m    from invoke import task[0m

[30;1m208 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m209 | [0m[35mLet's first rename our ``tasks.py`` to be ``docs.py``; no other changes are[0m
[30;1m210 | [0m[35mneeded there. Then we create a new ``tasks.py``, and for the sake of brevity[0m
[30;1m211 | [0m[35mpopulate it with a new, truly top level task called ``deploy``.[0m
[30;1m212 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m213 | [0m[35mFinally, we can use a new API member, the `.Collection` class, to bind this[0m
[30;1m214 | [0m[35mtask and the ``docs`` module into a single explicit namespace.  When Invoke[0m

[30;1m7 | [0m[35mthat fit our needs 100%." Specifically:[0m
[30;1m8 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m9 | [0m[35m- **Multiple tasks at once** - almost no other Python command-line oriented[0m
[30;1m10 | [0m[35m  libraries allow for invocations like::[0m
[30;1m11 | [0m[35m  [0m
[30;1m12 | [0m[35m    runner --core-opts task1 --task1-opts task2 --task2-opts[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m262[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000610[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Linux[0m
  Severity: [36mModerate[0m, Confidence: [36mLow[0m
  Filename: [33m/invoke-2.2.0/sites/www/prior-art.rst[0m
   Pattern: [32m\s(apt|apt\-get|aria2c|arp|ash|awk|base64|bash|bpftrace|busybox|cat|chmod|chown|cp|cpan|cpulimit|crontab|csh|curl|cut|dash|dd|diff|dmesg|dmsetup|dnf|docker|dpkg|easy_install|ed|emacs|env|expand|expect|facter|find|finger|flock|fmt|ftp|gawk|gdb|gimp|git|grep|head|iftop|ionice|ip|irb|jjs|journalctl|jrunscript|ksh|ld\.so|ldconfig|logsave|ltrace|lua|mail|mawk|mount|mtr|mv|mysql|nano|nawk|nc|nice|nl|nmap|node|od|openssl|perl|pg|php|pic|pico|pip|puppet|readelf|red|rlogin|rlwrap|rpm|rpmquery|rsync|ruby|run\-mailcap|run\-parts|rvim|scp|screen|script|sed|service|setarch|sftp|shuf|smbclient|socat|sort|sqlite3|ssh|start\-stop\-daemon|stdbuf|strace|systemctl|tail|tar|taskset|tclsh|tcpdump|tee|telnet|tftp|time|timeout|tmux|top|ul|unexpand|uniq|unshare|vi|vim|watch|wget|whois|wish|xargs|xxd|yum|zsh|zypper)\s[0m
[30;1m32 | [0m[35m  appealing options, but being built on argparse it doesn't support the[0m
[30;1m33 | [0m[35m  multi-task invocation we needed. Also has its own "prior art" list which is[0m
[30;1m34 | [0m[35m  worth your time.[0m
[30;1m35 | [0m[35m- `Baker <http://pypi.python.org/pypi/Baker/1.02>`_: Nice and simple, but[0m
[30;1m36 | [0m[35m  unfortunately too much so for our needs.[0m
[30;1m37 | [0m[35m- `Paver <http://paver.github.com/paver/>`_: Tries to do too much, clunky API,[0m
[30;1m38 | [0m[35m  user-hostile error messages, multi-task feature existed but was lacking.[0m

   Pattern: [32m\s(apt|apt\-get|aria2c|arp|ash|awk|base64|bash|bpftrace|busybox|cat|chmod|chown|cp|cpan|cpulimit|crontab|csh|curl|cut|dash|dd|diff|dmesg|dmsetup|dnf|docker|dpkg|easy_install|ed|emacs|env|expand|expect|facter|find|finger|flock|fmt|ftp|gawk|gdb|gimp|git|grep|head|iftop|ionice|ip|irb|jjs|journalctl|jrunscript|ksh|ld\.so|ldconfig|logsave|ltrace|lua|mail|mawk|mount|mtr|mv|mysql|nano|nawk|nc|nice|nl|nmap|node|od|openssl|perl|pg|php|pic|pico|pip|puppet|readelf|red|rlogin|rlwrap|rpm|rpmquery|rsync|ruby|run\-mailcap|run\-parts|rvim|scp|screen|script|sed|service|setarch|sftp|shuf|smbclient|socat|sort|sqlite3|ssh|start\-stop\-daemon|stdbuf|strace|systemctl|tail|tar|taskset|tclsh|tcpdump|tee|telnet|tftp|time|timeout|tmux|top|ul|unexpand|uniq|unshare|vi|vim|watch|wget|whois|wish|xargs|xxd|yum|zsh|zypper)\s[0m
[30;1m791 | [0m[35m        object's lifecycle, once all other sources (such as a runtime config[0m
[30;1m792 | [0m[35m        file or per-collection configurations) have been loaded. Loading from[0m
[30;1m793 | [0m[35m        the shell is not terrifically expensive, but must be done at a specific[0m
[30;1m794 | [0m[35m        point in time to ensure the "only known config keys are loaded from the[0m
[30;1m795 | [0m[35m        env" behavior works correctly.[0m
[30;1m796 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m797 | [0m[35m        See :ref:`env-vars` for details on this design decision and other info[0m

[30;1m1074 | [0m[35m            self._timer = threading.Timer(timeout, self.kill)[0m

[30;1m956 | [0m[35m        return env if replace_env else dict(os.environ, **env)[0m
[30;1m957 | [0m[35m[0m

   Pattern: [32m\s(apt|apt\-get|aria2c|arp|ash|awk|base64|bash|bpftrace|busybox|cat|chmod|chown|cp|cpan|cpulimit|crontab|csh|curl|cut|dash|dd|diff|dmesg|dmsetup|dnf|docker|dpkg|easy_install|ed|emacs|env|expand|expect|facter|find|finger|flock|fmt|ftp|gawk|gdb|gimp|git|grep|head|iftop|ionice|ip|irb|jjs|journalctl|jrunscript|ksh|ld\.so|ldconfig|logsave|ltrace|lua|mail|mawk|mount|mtr|mv|mysql|nano|nawk|nc|nice|nl|nmap|node|od|openssl|perl|pg|php|pic|pico|pip|puppet|readelf|red|rlogin|rlwrap|rpm|rpmquery|rsync|ruby|run\-mailcap|run\-parts|rvim|scp|screen|script|sed|service|setarch|sftp|shuf|smbclient|socat|sort|sqlite3|ssh|start\-stop\-daemon|stdbuf|strace|systemctl|tail|tar|taskset|tclsh|tcpdump|tee|telnet|tftp|time|timeout|tmux|top|ul|unexpand|uniq|unshare|vi|vim|watch|wget|whois|wish|xargs|xxd|yum|zsh|zypper)\s[0m
[30;1m30 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m31 | [0m[35mFabric 2 leverages many parts of Invoke's API, and allows (but does not[0m
[30;1m32 | [0m[35mrequire!) use of Invoke's CLI features, allowing multiple use cases (build[0m
[30;1m33 | [0m[35mtool, high level SSH lib, hybrid build/orchestration tool) to coexist without[0m
[30;1m34 | [0m[35mnegatively impacting each other.[0m
[30;1m35 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m36 | [0m[35m[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m514[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000610[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Linux[0m
  Severity: [36mModerate[0m, Confidence: [36mLow[0m
  Filename: [33m/invoke-2.2.0/sites/www/faq.rst[0m
   Pattern: [32m\s(apt|apt\-get|aria2c|arp|ash|awk|base64|bash|bpftrace|busybox|cat|chmod|chown|cp|cpan|cpulimit|crontab|csh|curl|cut|dash|dd|diff|dmesg|dmsetup|dnf|docker|dpkg|easy_install|ed|emacs|env|expand|expect|facter|find|finger|flock|fmt|ftp|gawk|gdb|gimp|git|grep|head|iftop|ionice|ip|irb|jjs|journalctl|jrunscript|ksh|ld\.so|ldconfig|logsave|ltrace|lua|mail|mawk|mount|mtr|mv|mysql|nano|nawk|nc|nice|nl|nmap|node|od|openssl|perl|pg|php|pic|pico|pip|puppet|readelf|red|rlogin|rlwrap|rpm|rpmquery|rsync|ruby|run\-mailcap|run\-parts|rvim|scp|screen|script|sed|service|setarch|sftp|shuf|smbclient|socat|sort|sqlite3|ssh|start\-stop\-daemon|stdbuf|strace|systemctl|tail|tar|taskset|tclsh|tcpdump|tee|telnet|tftp|time|timeout|tmux|top|ul|unexpand|uniq|unshare|vi|vim|watch|wget|whois|wish|xargs|xxd|yum|zsh|zypper)\s[0m
[30;1m23 | [0m[35mcodebase.[0m
[30;1m24 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m25 | [0m[35mWhen planning Fabric 2.x, having the "local" feature set as a standalone[0m
[30;1m26 | [0m[35mlibrary made sense, and it seemed plausible to design the SSH component as a[0m
[30;1m27 | [0m[35mseparate layer above. Thus, Invoke was created to focus exclusively on local[0m
[30;1m28 | [0m[35mand abstract concerns, leaving Fabric 2.x concerned only with servers and[0m
[30;1m29 | [0m[35mnetwork commands.[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m515[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000610[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Linux[0m
  Severity: [36mModerate[0m, Confidence: [36mLow[0m
  Filename: [33m/invoke-2.2.0/sites/www/faq.rst[0m
   Pattern: [32m\s(apt|apt\-get|aria2c|arp|ash|awk|base64|bash|bpftrace|busybox|cat|chmod|chown|cp|cpan|cpulimit|crontab|csh|curl|cut|dash|dd|diff|dmesg|dmsetup|dnf|docker|dpkg|easy_install|ed|emacs|env|expand|expect|facter|find|finger|flock|fmt|ftp|gawk|gdb|gimp|git|grep|head|iftop|ionice|ip|irb|jjs|journalctl|jrunscript|ksh|ld\.so|ldconfig|logsave|ltrace|lua|mail|mawk|mount|mtr|mv|mysql|nano|nawk|nc|nice|nl|nmap|node|od|openssl|perl|pg|php|pic|pico|pip|puppet|readelf|red|rlogin|rlwrap|rpm|rpmquery|rsync|ruby|run\-mailcap|run\-parts|rvim|scp|screen|script|sed|service|setarch|sftp|shuf|smbclient|socat|sort|sqlite3|ssh|start\-stop\-daemon|stdbuf|strace|systemctl|tail|tar|taskset|tclsh|tcpdump|tee|telnet|tftp|time|timeout|tmux|top|ul|unexpand|uniq|unshare|vi|vim|watch|wget|whois|wish|xargs|xxd|yum|zsh|zypper)\s[0m
[30;1m17 | [0m[35mservers/hosts, remote shell commands, and file transfer).[0m
[30;1m18 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m19 | [0m[35mFor use cases requiring both feature sets, this arrangement worked well.[0m
[30;1m20 | [0m[35mHowever, over time it became clear many users only needed one or the other,[0m
[30;1m21 | [0m[35mwith local-only users resenting heavy SSH/crypto install requirements, and[0m
[30;1m22 | [0m[35mremote-focused users struggling with API limitations caused by the hybrid[0m
[30;1m23 | [0m[35mcodebase.[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m516[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000610[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Linux[0m
  Severity: [36mModerate[0m, Confidence: [36mLow[0m
  Filename: [33m/invoke-2.2.0/sites/www/faq.rst[0m
   Pattern: [32m\s(apt|apt\-get|aria2c|arp|ash|awk|base64|bash|bpftrace|busybox|cat|chmod|chown|cp|cpan|cpulimit|crontab|csh|curl|cut|dash|dd|diff|dmesg|dmsetup|dnf|docker|dpkg|easy_install|ed|emacs|env|expand|expect|facter|find|finger|flock|fmt|ftp|gawk|gdb|gimp|git|grep|head|iftop|ionice|ip|irb|jjs|journalctl|jrunscript|ksh|ld\.so|ldconfig|logsave|ltrace|lua|mail|mawk|mount|mtr|mv|mysql|nano|nawk|nc|nice|nl|nmap|node|od|openssl|perl|pg|php|pic|pico|pip|puppet|readelf|red|rlogin|rlwrap|rpm|rpmquery|rsync|ruby|run\-mailcap|run\-parts|rvim|scp|screen|script|sed|service|setarch|sftp|shuf|smbclient|socat|sort|sqlite3|ssh|start\-stop\-daemon|stdbuf|strace|systemctl|tail|tar|taskset|tclsh|tcpdump|tee|telnet|tftp|time|timeout|tmux|top|ul|unexpand|uniq|unshare|vi|vim|watch|wget|whois|wish|xargs|xxd|yum|zsh|zypper)\s[0m
[30;1m13 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m14 | [0m[35mFabric (1.x and earlier) was a hybrid project implementing two feature sets:[0m
[30;1m15 | [0m[35mtask execution (organization of task functions, execution of them via CLI, and[0m
[30;1m16 | [0m[35mlocal shell commands) and high level SSH actions (organization of[0m
[30;1m17 | [0m[35mservers/hosts, remote shell commands, and file transfer).[0m
[30;1m18 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m19 | [0m[35mFor use cases requiring both feature sets, this arrangement worked well.[0m

[30;1m228 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m229 | [0m[35mFor example, the following command prints (to stdout) a script which works for[0m
[30;1m230 | [0m[35m``zsh``, instructs ``zsh`` to use it for the ``inv`` and ``invoke`` programs,[0m
[30;1m231 | [0m[35mand calls ``invoke --complete`` at runtime to get dynamic completion[0m
[30;1m232 | [0m[35minformation::[0m
[30;1m233 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m234 | [0m[35m    $ invoke --print-completion-script zsh[0m

[30;1m241 | [0m[35monly has a single binary name (``fab``); if you wanted to get Fabric completion[0m
[30;1m242 | [0m[35min ``bash``, you would say::[0m
[30;1m243 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m244 | [0m[35m    $ fab --print-completion-script bash[0m
[30;1m245 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m246 | [0m[35mIn the rest of this section, we'll use ``inv`` in examples, but please remember[0m
[30;1m247 | [0m[35mto replace it with the program you're actually using, if it's not Invoke[0m
[30;1m248 | [0m[35mitself![0m

[30;1m1201 | [0m[35m  monkeypatched Popen code used for ``invoke.runner.run`` with a[0m
[30;1m1202 | [0m[35m  non-monkeypatched approach that works better on non-POSIX platforms like[0m
[30;1m1203 | [0m[35m  Windows, and also attempts to handle encoding and locale issues more[0m

[30;1m1207 | [0m[35m  and performs explicit encoding/decoding based on detected or explicitly[0m

[30;1m918 | [0m[35m    running top level Python code outside of any ``run`` function calls)[0m
[30;1m919 | [0m[35m    will now trigger exit code ``1``, as that is how the Python interpreter[0m
[30;1m920 | [0m[35m    typically behaves if you ``KeyboardInterrupt`` it outside of a live[0m
[30;1m921 | [0m[35m    REPL.[0m

[30;1m709 | [0m[35m      ``Config`` and using its ``env_prefix`` attribute;[0m
[30;1m710 | [0m[35m    - or if you were relying on how standalone ``Config`` objects defaulted to[0m
[30;1m711 | [0m[35m      having a ``None`` value for ``env_prefix``, and thus loaded env vars[0m
[30;1m712 | [0m[35m      without an ``INVOKE_`` style prefix.[0m
[30;1m713 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m714 | [0m[35m      See new documentation for this functionality at[0m

[30;1m139 | [0m[35mconfiguration to set ``tasks.auto_dash_names`` to ``False`` in one of the[0m

[30;1m54 | [0m[35m=================[0m
[30;1m55 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m56 | [0m[35mBy default, a task's function name is used as its namespace identifier, but you[0m
[30;1m57 | [0m[35mmay override this by giving a ``name`` argument to either `@task <.task>` (i.e.[0m
[30;1m58 | [0m[35mat definition time) or `.Collection.add_task` (i.e. at binding/attachment[0m
[30;1m59 | [0m[35mtime).[0m
[30;1m60 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m61 | [0m[35mFor example, say you have a variable name collision in your tasks module --[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m741[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000610[0m

[30;1m348 | [0m[35mbest fits your needs.[0m

[30;1m221 | [0m[35m    As with the default task module, you can override this default loading[0m
[30;1m222 | [0m[35m    behavior by declaring a ``ns`` or ``namespace`` `.Collection` object at top[0m
[30;1m223 | [0m[35m    level in the loaded module.[0m

[30;1m116 | [0m[35mDashes vs underscores[0m
[30;1m117 | [0m[35m---------------------[0m
[30;1m118 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m119 | [0m[35mIn the common case of functions-as-tasks, you'll often find yourself writing[0m
[30;1m120 | [0m[35mtask names that contain underscores::[0m
[30;1m121 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m122 | [0m[35m    @task[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m745[0m[34m of [0m[33m762[0m[31m ]--[0m

[30;1m64 | [0m[35mInvoke is a Python (2.7 and 3.4+) library for managing shell-oriented[0m
[30;1m65 | [0m[35msubprocesses and organizing executable Python code into CLI-invokable tasks. It[0m
[30;1m66 | [0m[35mdraws inspiration from various sources (``make``/``rake``, Fabric 1.x, etc) to[0m
[30;1m67 | [0m[35marrive at a powerful & clean feature set.[0m
[30;1m68 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m69 | [0m[35mTo find out what's new in this version of Invoke, please see `the changelog[0m
[30;1m70 | [0m[35m<https://pyinvoke.org/changelog.html#{}>`_.[0m
